key_issues: The interpretation of Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules 2017 regarding the abandonment of opposition to a trademark registration application is a key issue.
The applicability of Rule 45(2) when the opponent fails to submit evidence or a statement of intention to rely on the notice of opposition is a crucial point of contention.

The requirement for the opponent to leave evidence with the Registrar or intimate their intention to rely on the facts stated in the notice of opposition within the prescribed time is a vital consideration.
The issue of deemed abandonment of opposition under Rule 45(2) and its implications on the trademark registration process is a significant concern.
The role of the Registrar in determining whether the opposition has been abandoned and allowing the application to proceed further is an important issue.
The potential consequences of abandonment of opposition on the rights of the opponent and the applicant in the trademark registration process need to be considered.
The interplay between the Trade Marks Act 1999 and the Trade Marks Rules 2017 in relation to opposition proceedings and the abandonment of opposition is a key aspect.
The burden of proof on the opponent to submit evidence or a statement of intention to rely on the notice of opposition within the prescribed time is a significant issue.
The potential for the applicant to proceed with the registration of their trademark if the opposition is deemed abandoned is a critical consideration.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: M/s V-Guard Industries Ltd. vs. M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd. & Anr.**

**Background:**
The case revolves around a trademark opposition proceeding initiated by M/s V-Guard Industries Ltd. (Appellant) against M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd. (Respondent 1) under Section 21 of the Trade Mark Act, 1999. Respondent 1 had applied for the registration of its trademark "LIVGUARD ZING" in respect of batteries, invertors, and similar goods. The Appellant opposed this application, and the Respondent 1 filed a counter-statement in response to the notice of opposition.

**Legal Issues:**
The primary issue in this case is the interpretation of Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017, which deals with the Evidence in Support of Opposition. Specifically, the court had to decide whether the Appellant's failure to file evidence in support of its opposition within the prescribed time limit, as stipulated in Rule 45, resulted in the abandonment of its opposition.

**Arguments:**
The Appellant argued that the language of Rule 45 was ambiguous and that the phrase "leave with the Registrar" was unclear. The Appellant contended that it had not abandoned its opposition and that the Respondent 1's application for registration should not be allowed to proceed.

The Respondent 1, on the other hand, argued that the Appellant's failure to file evidence in support of its opposition within the prescribed time limit, as required by Rule 45, resulted in the deemed abandonment of its opposition.

**Court Findings:**
The court observed that Rule 45 is "very unhappily worded" and that the expression "leave with the Registrar" is unclear. The court noted that Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules, which deals with "leaving of documents," provides some guidance on this issue. However, the court ultimately held that the Appellant's failure to file evidence in support of its opposition within the prescribed time limit resulted in the deemed abandonment of its opposition, as stipulated in Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017.

**Decision:**
The court dismissed the Appellant's appeal and upheld the order of the Deputy Registrar of Trademarks, which had allowed the Respondent 1's application for registration to proceed due to the Appellant's deemed abandonment of its opposition. The court ordered that there shall be no order as to the costs of the proceedings.

In summary, the court's decision in this case emphasizes the importance of adhering to the procedural requirements of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017, and provides guidance on the interpretation of Rule 45 in cases where an opponent fails to file evidence in support of its opposition within the prescribed time limit.

time mentioned therein, he shall be deemed to have abandoned his

expression “leave with the Registrar”. This is an expression to which

My attention has been invited to Rule 8 of the Trade Mark

“8. 
Leaving of documents, etc.— All applications, notices, 
statements or other documents or any fees authorised or required 
by the Act or the rules to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or 
to the Trade Marks Registry in relation to a trademark on the 
Register of trademarks on the notified date or for which an 
application for registration is pending on, or is made on or after the 
notified date, shall be made, served, left or sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry:

permit the filing of certain forms or documents, other than the 
application for the registration of a trademark in any other office of 
the Trade Marks Registry.” 
 
7. 
Unfortunately, Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules is just as 
nebulous as Rule 45.  It requires the opponent, opposing the 
registration of a trade mark, to “leave with the Registrar”, evidence by 
way of affidavit.  It is difficult to understand the expression “leave 
with the Registrar”.  At any rate, it is not an expression which should 
ordinarily find place in a legislative document.

The case of the appellant, as argued by Ms. Bhabna Das, 
learned Counsel for the appellant, and as set out in the present appeal, 
is that 7th May 2018 being the last date by which the evidence in 
opposition was required to be filed by the appellant, attempts were 
made to upload the evidence on the website of the Registrar of Trade 
Marks, but that, as the website was non-functional, this could not be 
done.  As a result, submits Ms. Bhabna Das, the evidence was sent to 
the office of the Registrar by courier.  It is an admitted position that 
the evidence in opposition as sent by the appellant was, in fact, 
received by the office of the learned Registrar on 10th May 2018, i.e.,

mere three days beyond the last date for “leaving” of the evidence.  
 
9. 
As is apparent, the impugned order has proceeded on the 
premise that, as the evidence in terms of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark 
Rules had not been filed within two months from the service of the 
counter statement of Respondent 1 on the appellant, the opposition of 
the appellant was deemed to have been abandoned by application of 
sub-rule (2) of Rule 45.  
 
10. 
At a bare glance, the impugned order is incorrect, as Rule 45(1) 
does not use the expression “filed”.  What Rule 45(1) requires is that 
the evidence must be “left with the Registrar”.  Where the statute is 
ambiguous, the benefit of ambiguity has to go to the citizen. This 
would be especially so where the statute confers a valuable 
commercial right on the citizen. It cannot be gainsaid that, having 
submitted the notice of opposition, opposing the application of 
Respondent 1 for registration of the Trade Mark, the tendering of 
evidence in support of the opposition was a valuable commercial right 
which enured in favor of the opponent/appellant. There is no 
conceivable reason as to why, having filed the notice of opposition, 
the appellant would abandon the opposition.  That the appellant did 
not, in fact, do so, is manifest by the fact that, on 28th
 
 August 2018, 
the appellant filed an application for extension of time, purportedly 
under Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act read with Rule 109 of the 
Trade Mark Rules, in Form TM-M, as required by the said rules.  
11. 
The application has not been considered by the learned Deputy 
Registrar while passing the impugned order. In the application, it was 
specifically submitted that the website of the learned Registrar of

Trade Marks was non-functional on 7th May 2018, as a result of

 May 2018, the evidence in opposition was sent by the 
appellant by courier.  
12. 
As already noticed, it is an admitted position that the evidence 
in opposition was indeed received by the office of the learned 
Registrar on 10th
 
 May 2018.     
13. 
The issue before the court is whether, in these circumstances 
and in the backdrop of the existing statutory scenario as contained in 
the Trade Marks Act and Trade Marks Rules, this Court should sustain 
the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar, vide the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018, to treat the opposition filed by the appellant, 
to the application of Respondent 1 seeking registration of the 
“LIVGUARD ZING” mark, as having been abandoned.  
14. 
Having heard Ms. Bhabna Das, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Jithin M George, learned Counsel for Respondent 1, 
in my considered opinion, the answer to this query has necessarily to 
be in the negative.  
 
15. 
Two issues would arise for consideration. The first is whether 
there was, in fact, delay on the part of the appellant in complying with 
the requirement of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules. The second is 
whether, assuming there was any such delay, the learned Registrar 
was empowered to condone the delay or to extend the time for 
compliance with Rule 45.  
 
16. 
Addressing the first issue first, Rule 45 (1) stipulates that,

within two months from service of the copy of the counter statement 
filed by the trade mark applicant, the opponent opposing the 
registration of the mark is required to leave, with the Registrar, 
evidence by way of affidavit in support of the opposition.  Rule 45(1) 
further requires the opponent to the registration of the trade mark to 
deliver, to the applicant seeking registration, copies of the affidavit 
left with the Registrar and to intimate the Registrar in that regard.   
 
17. 
Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules states that all documents, which 
are required “to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or to the Trade 
Marks Registry”, in respect of a Trade Mark in respect of which an 
application seeking registration is pending, “shall be made, served, 
left, or sent or paid to the appropriate office of the Trade Marks 
Registry”. 
 
18. 
As already observed, the provision is as nebulous as can be.  
The Rule, envelops, in one parenthesis, the expressions “made” 
“served”, “left”, “sent” and “paid” and refers to such making, serving, 
leaving, sending, or paying “to the appropriate office of the Trade 
Marks Registry”. 
 
19. 
Given the nature of these provisions and the fact that they affect 
a valuable right vested in an opponent who seeks to oppose the 
registration of a trade mark, I am of the considered opinion that, in the 
facts of the present case, the appellant won’t be entitled to the benefit 
of the ambiguity inherent in this provision.  
 
20. 
The appellant, in its application seeking extension of time as 
filed before the learned Deputy Registrar, as well as in the present 
Digitally Signed

appeal, has stated, on affidavit, that the attempts at e-filing of the 
evidence in support of the appellant’s objections, on 7th
 
 May 2018, 
could not succeed as the website of the learned Registrar of Trade 
Marks was non-functional.  The impugned order does not seek to 
discountenance this assertion.  Notice was issued in the present 
appeal, and there is no affidavit filed by way of response, denying this 
fact.  
21. 
There is no reason, therefore, for this Court to disbelieve the 
appellant and presume that, in fact, no attempt was made by the 
appellant to e-file the objections on 7th May 2018, especially as, on the 
very next day i.e., 8th May 2018, the objections were in fact sent by 
courier.  This is not, therefore, a case in which the appellant exhibited 
any callous or negligent indolence.   The fact that, on 8th May 2018, 
the appellant did indeed courier the evidence in support of the 
opposition to the office of the learned Registrar of Trade Marks, 
compels this Court to believe the assertion, in the present appeal, also 
contained in the application for extension of time filed before the 
learned Registrar with the evidence in support of the opposition was in 
fact forwarded to the office of the learned Registrar electronically on 
7th
 
 May 2018, but that the attempt could not succeed as the website 
was non-functional.  
22. 
Such an attempt, in my view, would fall within the broad 
embrace of the expression “made, served, left, sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry”, as employed in Rule 
8 of the Trade Marks Rules.  
 
23. 
Even otherwise, it is well-settled that, while procedural 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000136 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021                                                                       Page 8 of 9  
 
   
provisions are required to be accorded their due deference, they cannot 
be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late, 
especially as, prima facie, the appellant did make efforts to “leave” the 
evidence in support of the opposition with the office of the learned 
Registrar  within the time stipulated in that regard in Rule 45(1) of the  
Trade Marks Rules. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018 would stand set aside.  
26. 
Resultantly, the learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take into 
account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a 
view thereon.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000136 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021                                                                       Page 9 of 9  
 
   
27. 
I am informed that, after the impugned order was passed, the 
mark of Respondent 1 has proceeded to registration.  
 
28. 
Needless to say, in view of the decision taken today, the 
registration of the Trade Mark shall remain subject to the outcome of 
the view to be taken by the learned Deputy Registrar on the opposition 
filed by the appellant.  
 
29. 
In order that equities are not unnecessarily prejudiced, the  
learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take a decision on the 
appellant's notice of opposition, after following due process in that 
regard, within a period of three months from today.  
 
30. 
For this purpose, both sides are directed to present themselves 
before the office of the learned Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks on 
16th
 
 January 2023 at 11:00 a.m. 
31. 
The learned Deputy Registrar would proceed with the matter 
with all due expedition.  
 
32. 
Both sides are directed not to seek any adjournment from the 
learned Deputy Registrar. 
 
33. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no order as to 
costs.  
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J. 
 
JANUARY 6, 2023

According to the PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd." (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000136), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021) filed by M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. against an order dated 06.01.2023. The order deemed the opposition to the registration of the trademark "LIVGUARD ZING" by M/S Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd. to be abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017.

The application for registration was filed on 11th July 2014, and a notice of opposition was filed by the appellant on 2nd June 2016. The respondent filed a counterstatement on 7th March 2018, which was served electronically on the appellant on the same day. However, the appellant failed to submit evidence in support of the opposition or intimate to the Registrar that they did not desire to adduce evidence within the prescribed time.

The Court noted that Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules requires the opponent to submit evidence or intimate their intention to rely on the facts stated in the notice of opposition within two months of the service of the counterstatement. Since the appellant took no action, their opposition was deemed abandoned. The Court ordered that the application for registration proceed further as per the rules, with no order as to costs. tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd." (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000136), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021. The appellant, M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd., was represented by Ms. Bhabna Das, Mr. Mukul Kumar, and Mr. Vizzy George, while the respondents were M/S Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd and another.

The case revolves around a trademark opposition. The appellant attempted to upload evidence on the Registrar of Trade Marks' website by May 7, 2018, but due to technical issues, they sent it via courier, which was received by the Registrar's office on May 10, 2018, three days past the deadline. The Registrar deemed the opposition abandoned, citing Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules.

The appellant argued that the expression "leave with the Registrar" in Rule 45 is ambiguous and that they had submitted the evidence within a reasonable time frame. The court noted that the impugned order was incorrect, as Rule 45(1) requires evidence to be "left with the Registrar," not "filed." The court also stated that the benefit of ambiguity should go to the citizen, especially when a valuable commercial right is involved.

The appellant had filed a notice of opposition and later applied for an extension of time to submit evidence. The court's decision is based on the interpretation of the Trade Mark Rules and the rights of the opponent/appellant. (Source: PDF document, pages 1-4 of 9)

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd" (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000136, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal by M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. against the decision of the Deputy Registrar to treat their opposition to the registration of the "LIVGUARD ZING" mark as abandoned.

The appellant had attempted to e-file evidence in support of their opposition on May 7, 2018, but the Trade Marks Registry website was non-functional. The evidence was sent by courier on May 8, 2018, and received by the Registrar's office on May 10, 2018. The respondent, M/S Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd, argued that the appellant had delayed in complying with Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules, which requires evidence to be filed within two months of the service of the counter-statement.

The court considered two issues: whether there was a delay on the part of the appellant and whether the Registrar was empowered to condone the delay. The court noted that the provisions of the Trade Mark Rules, particularly Rule 8, were ambiguous. However, the court ultimately decided in favor of the appellant, stating that the decision of the Deputy Registrar to treat the opposition as abandoned should not be sustained. (Source: PDF document, pages 1-9)

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the court document from the PDF "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd.", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision on the appeal filed by M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. against M/S Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd. The appeal, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021, was allowed with no order as to costs.

The court ruled in favor of the appellant, setting aside the impugned order dated August 30, 2018, which had treated the opposition as abandoned due to late submission of evidence. The court directed the Deputy Registrar to consider the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a decision within three months.

The Respondent's trade mark had proceeded to registration after the impugned order, but the court stated that the registration shall remain subject to the outcome of the view to be taken by the Deputy Registrar on the opposition filed by the appellant.

Key dates mentioned in the document include January 6, 2023, when the judgment was passed, and January 10, 2023, when the document was digitally signed. The parties were directed to present themselves before the Deputy Registrar on January 16, 2023, at 11:00 a.m. The court also instructed both sides not to seek any adjournment from the Deputy Registrar.

Source: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd. (PDF) Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000136, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021.

MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd.", the High Court of Delhi ruled in favor of the appellant, M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd. The court set aside the impugned order dated August 30, 2018, which treated the opposition as abandoned due to late submission of evidence. The court directed the Deputy Registrar to consider the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant. The decision was made on January 10, 2023, as stated in the digitally signed document by Kamla Rawat. The case number is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 80/2021, and the Neutral Citation Number is 2023/DHC/000136. The court prioritized the appellant's right to oppose registration of a trade mark, considering it sacrosanct. (Source: PDF "35. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd.  v. MS Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd.")

provisions are required to be accorded their due deference, they cannot 
be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late,

24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order
